question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('e8f518c7-23cb-464f-a64b-b3731c76ab3f'), title='Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('5de910de-598d-4db7-8334-f34d9b13204d'), title='Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

(b) Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference?', body='This market will resolve YES if either Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024, or if he makes a public statement about Bitcoin before the conference.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('97622e9f-6eeb-4b85-b472-47e3ce064a23'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference (2) Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This question will resolve YES if (1) Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, and (2) Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('e6da6cb5-e222-4ef9-ab93-0635ee04999d'), title='Given that Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public statement about Bitcoin before the conference?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

Resolution criteria for P: The market resolves YES if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the conference.

Resolution criteria for Q: The market resolves YES if Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE

0.73

RECEIVED

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, we need to consider the relationships between the various events defined by P, not_P, Q, and their combinations.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's public interest in Bitcoin and his previous attendance at similar events. Given his high-profile status, there is a reasonable probability he might attend, so I would estimate this probability around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complement of P. If P is 0.60, then not_P should be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is it possible Musk will attend?)**: This question is essentially asking the same as P, so I would set this equal to P, which is 0.60.

4. **Q (Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This is somewhat independent of P, as he could make a statement without attending the conference. However, given his history of commenting on Bitcoin, I would estimate this at 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This requires both events to happen. The probability of both happening can be estimated using the product of their probabilities if we consider them independent, so I would estimate this at 0.60 * 0.50 = 0.30.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This is a bit trickier, as it requires the union of the two probabilities. Using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q, we can calculate this as 0.60 + 0.50 - 0.30 = 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs but P does not)**: This means Musk makes a statement but does not attend. Assuming independence, this would be Q * not_P = 0.50 * 0.40 = 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Q given P)**: This is a conditional probability. If we assume that if Musk shows up, he is more likely to make a statement, I would estimate this at 0.70.

In summary, the relationships between these events are important. P and not_P are complementary, while Q can occur independently of P. The calculations for P_and_Q, P_or_Q, and Q_and_not_P rely on the assumed independence of P and Q, which is a reasonable assumption given the context.

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.70

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.60 = 1 - 0.40 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.80 + 0.30 - 0.50 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.50 - 1, 0) <= 0.30 <= min(0.60, 0.50) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.50) <= 0.80 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.80 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.30 / 0.70 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE

failed_check_3, failed_check_6 consistency checks failed!

Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.43

0.6

question.title: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, the probabilities will be assessed based on various factors such as his past behavior, current interests, and the significance of the event. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This prediction will likely be influenced by Musk's history of engaging with cryptocurrency events and his public persona. Given his prominence in the crypto community, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is around 0.65, then not_P would be around 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially asking for the same thing as P, so it should have a similar probability, likely around 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference?)**: Musk's tendency to make public statements about Bitcoin could suggest a moderate probability here as well, possibly around 0.60.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events happening would depend on the correlation between them. If P is 0.65 and Q is 0.60, a reasonable estimate for P_and_Q could be around 0.50, considering they are related but not perfectly correlated.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula for probabilities of unions. If P is 0.65 and Q is 0.60, P_or_Q would be approximately 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q and not_P occur?)**: This combines the probability of Q with the complement of P. Given Q is 0.60 and not_P is 0.35, a rough estimate could be around 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability would likely be higher than the baseline probability of Q, possibly around 0.70, reflecting that if Musk shows up, he may also make a statement.

Overall, these estimates need to be consistent with each other, adhering to the rules laid out. For example, the sum of probabilities for P and not_P must equal 1, and the relationships between P, Q, P_and_Q, and P_or_Q must hold true based on standard probability rules.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.60,
P_and_Q: 0.50,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.70

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.75 + 0.50 - 0.60 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.60 - 1, 0) <= 0.50 <= min(0.65, 0.60) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.60) <= 0.75 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.60) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.75 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.50 / 0.70 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.60,
P_and_Q: 0.50,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.70

0.65

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

In this scenario, we are evaluating several questions regarding Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. Each question is binary, meaning it will resolve to either YES or NO, and they are interconnected in various ways.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is a direct question about Musk's attendance. Given his previous engagement with Bitcoin-related events, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend, let's say 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P. Thus, if P is 0.60, not_P should be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This question is similar to P, so I would expect it to have a similar probability estimate of 0.60, as it is asking about the possibility rather than certainty.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference?)**: This question is independent of P but could be related in some way. Given Musk's history of making statements about Bitcoin, I would estimate this probability to be around 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events happening can be estimated using the multiplication rule for independent events: P_and_Q = P * Q. Therefore, if P is 0.60 and Q is 0.50, then P_and_Q would be 0.30.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula: P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Using the previous estimates, this would be 0.60 + 0.50 - 0.30 = 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This requires estimating the joint probability of Q occurring while P does not. Since not_P is 0.40, we can estimate this as Q * not_P = 0.50 * 0.40 = 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability. If we assume that if Musk shows up, he is more likely to make a statement, we could estimate this to be higher, say 0.70.

After calculating these probabilities, I will check them against the consistency rules to ensure they are mathematically valid and make adjustments if necessary.

para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.70

or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.50) <= 0.80 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.80 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.30 / 0.70 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE

In this scenario, we are evaluating the likelihood of various events related to Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is contingent upon Elon Musk being present at the conference. Given his previous engagements and interest in Bitcoin, I would assess this probability to be moderately high. 

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If P is relatively high, not_P will be lower. 

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability should be similar to P, as it essentially asks the same question but in a different form. 

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the conference?)**: This depends on Musk's tendency to engage with the media and public, particularly regarding Bitcoin. Given his history, I would assign a moderate probability here as well.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This is a joint probability that requires both events to happen. Given that both events have moderate probabilities, I would expect this probability to be lower than either P or Q individually, but still positive.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability should be higher than both P and Q individually, as it accounts for either event occurring. However, if both events are unlikely, it may not be as high as expected.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q happen while not_P happens?)**: This is a conditional probability that requires Q to occur while P does not. This could happen if Musk makes a statement but does not attend the conference, which could be plausible.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P happens, will Q happen?)**: This conditional probability would depend on the likelihood that Musk would make a statement if he were to attend the conference. If P is true, Q is likely to be true as well, but not guaranteed.

**Independence and Relationships**: P and Q are not entirely independent; Musk's attendance (P) could influence his likelihood of making a statement (Q). Therefore, the probabilities must reflect this relationship to ensure consistency across the various derived probabilities.
